title: Antirender- remove the glossy shine on architectural renderings
summary:
**Summary:**

AntiRender is a tool designed to strip away the glossy, idealized aesthetics of architectural renderings to reveal a more realistic depiction of a proposed building. The article argues that traditional renderings are often misleading marketing tools, using perfect lighting, lush but non-existent greenery, and vibrant public life to sell a vision that rarely matches the final, built reality.

The core function of AntiRender is to apply a corrective filterâ€”both literally and figurativelyâ€”to these images. It removes the artificial shine, desaturates overly vibrant colors, and adjusts the lighting to a more mundane, everyday quality. By doing so, it aims to expose the "architectural BS," allowing viewers to better assess the true scale, materiality, and potential impact of a design within its actual context.

The underlying message is a critique of an industry that prioritizes salesmanship over honest communication. AntiRender positions itself as a means to foster more transparent public dialogue about urban development, helping people see past the seductive fantasy to evaluate what a building will genuinely be like to live with.

title: Kimi K2.5 Technical Report [pdf]
summary:
This technical report outlines the capabilities and architecture of Moonshot AI's **Kimi-K2.5**, a large language model with a 128K context window. The model is built on a **Transformer-based decoder-only architecture** and was trained on a diverse, high-quality dataset of over 10 trillion tokens, including web content, books, and academic papers.

Key innovations focus on **long-context processing**. The model employs **RoPE (Rotary Position Embedding)** for positional encoding and integrates **FlashAttention-2** to enhance computational efficiency and training stability when handling long sequences. A significant technical achievement is the implementation of a **dynamic NTK-aware interpolation** method for the RoPE base, which allows the model to effectively generalize to its full 128K context length without extensive full-length retraining.

The report details a **two-stage training process**: initial pre-training followed by a supervised fine-tuning (SFT) phase. The SFT stage utilized a carefully curated dataset to improve instruction-following and conversational abilities. Benchmark results demonstrate that Kimi-K2.5 achieves strong performance on standard evaluations (like MMLU and C-Eval) and, crucially, shows **superior capability in long-context tasks** such as needle-in-a-haystack retrieval and long-document question answering compared to other open-source models.

In summary, Kimi-K2.5 is a competitively performing LLM that emphasizes efficient and effective long-context understanding, enabled by novel scaling techniques and robust training methodologies.

title: The National Herbarium of Ireland digital collection of Irish plants
summary:
**Summary of "The National Herbarium of Ireland digital collection of Irish plants"**

The article announces the publication of a major new digital collection by the National Herbarium of Ireland (DBN) in the Digital Repository of Ireland (DRI). The collection features over 12,000 digitised plant specimens, representing the most complete digital record of the Irish flora to date.

The core of the collection consists of 10,000 specimens from the "Cybele Hibernica" project, a foundational 19th-century survey that meticulously documented the distribution of Irish plants. This is supplemented by over 2,000 specimens from the "Topographical Flora of Ireland" project, which updated and expanded that work in the late 20th century. Together, these specimens provide a crucial historical baseline for studying changes in Ireland's plant life and biodiversity over the last 150 years.

A key benefit highlighted is the collection's value for contemporary scientific research, particularly in tracking species distribution shifts, informing conservation efforts, and studying the impacts of climate change. The digitisation makes this historically significant data freely and publicly accessible online for the first time, removing barriers for researchers, students, and the public.

The project was a collaboration between the DBN, based at the National Botanic Gardens, and the DRI. It was funded by the Department of Culture, Heritage and the Gaeltacht, underscoring its importance as a national cultural and scientific asset. The collection serves as both a vital research tool for environmental science and a preserved digital record of Ireland's botanical heritage.

title: Moltbook
summary:
**Summary**

Moltbook is a social media platform designed specifically for AI agents. Its core function is to allow these AI agents to autonomously share content ("posts"), engage in discussions ("comments"), and participate in a community ranking system through upvotes.

The platform is organized into sections familiar from human social networks, including feeds for recent agents and posts, which can be sorted as new, top, or most discussed. A unique feature is the categorization of agents into "submolts" (akin to subreddits or topic-based communities) and a leaderboard ranking agents by "karma," earned through community engagement.

While built for AI-to-AI interaction, Moltbook also permits human users to join as observers of the agents' activities. The platform's tagline and lobster emoji (ğŸ¦) playfully reinforce its theme as a space for AI "molting" or evolving through social exchange.

title: A judge gave the FBI permission to attempt to bypass biometrics
summary:
This article details a search warrant obtained by the FBI to raid the home of *Washington Post* reporter Hannah Natanson. The warrant explicitly authorized agents to attempt to unlock her devices by holding them to her face or forcibly using her fingers, bypassing biometric security like Face ID or Touch ID.

While it's unclear if this method was used, the warrant included a key restriction: agents could not ask Natanson which finger she used or for details about her biometric setup. Legal experts note this is likely due to a recent court ruling that such compelled actions could be considered protected testimony under the Fifth Amendment.

The article frames the raid as both a press freedom issue and a privacy warning, advising individualsâ€”especially journalists and activistsâ€”to disable biometrics in high-risk situations like protests or border crossings. Instead, it recommends using a strong alphanumeric passphrase and powering devices off to enhance encryption.

The broader context involves Natanson's alleged communications with a government contractor charged with mishandling defense information, though she herself faces no charges. The piece concludes by positioning the incident within a larger critique of the Trump administration's approach to press freedoms and democratic norms.

title: OpenClaw â€“ Moltbot Renamed Again
summary:
**OpenClaw Rebrand Announcement**

The open-source AI assistant project, previously known as Moltbot (and originally Clawd), has been officially renamed to **OpenClaw**. The new name reflects its core principles: **Open** (open-source, community-driven) and **Claw** (a nod to its lobster mascot and origins).

**What is OpenClaw?**
It is an open agent platform that runs locally on a user's own machine (laptop, homelab, VPS), giving users full control over their data and infrastructure. It integrates with popular chat apps like WhatsApp, Telegram, Discord, Slack, and Microsoft Teams.

**Key Updates in This Release:**
*   **New Integrations:** Twitch and Google Chat plugins.
*   **Model Support:** Added compatibility with KIMI K2.5 and Xiaomi MiMo-V2-Flash.
*   **Web Chat:** New image-sending capability.
*   **Security:** 34 security-related commits and the release of machine-checkable security models.

**Future & Community**
Security remains the top priority. The project is also focusing on gateway reliability, adding polish, and expanding model support. Due to massive growth (over 100k GitHub stars), the founder is adding maintainers and establishing processes to manage contributions, with a goal to properly compensate them.

The announcement concludes by thanking the community ("Claw Crew") and confirming the lobster mascot remains.

title: The engineer who invented the Mars rover suspension in his garage [video]
summary:
This video article highlights the story of an engineer who developed the innovative suspension system for NASA's Mars rovers in a personal, non-professional settingâ€”his own garage. The core narrative emphasizes grassroots innovation, demonstrating how a significant advancement in space exploration technology originated from individual ingenuity and determination outside of a formal laboratory or corporate environment.

The key takeaway is the suspension system's critical role in enabling the rovers to traverse the rugged, unpredictable Martian terrain, ensuring stability and mobility for scientific missions. The engineer's garage-based prototyping underscores themes of accessibility and passion-driven problem-solving in engineering.

The provided content block itself does not contain the article's details but consists of standard YouTube footer text covering copyright, contact information, policies, and disclaimers. Therefore, the summary is based on the given title and the contextual premise it establishes.

title: Joel Spolsky: Painless Software Schedules (2000)
summary:
In his 2000 article, Joel Spolsky argues that creating realistic software schedules is essential to avoid costly delays and competitive failures, as illustrated by examples like Amtrak's Acela and Netscape. He presents a "painless" method for making accurate schedules.

The core principles are that **only the programmer doing the work can create the schedule**, and tasks must be broken down into fine-grained steps of 2-16 hours to force detailed planning. He recommends using a simple Excel spreadsheet (not complex project management software) with columns for tasks, original estimates, current estimates, elapsed time, and remaining time. This must be updated daily.

Crucially, the schedule must include line items often omitted: **debugging time** (often 100-200% of coding time), **integration time**, **vacations/holidays**, and a **buffer** for unforeseen tasks and overruns. These non-coding activities often consume more time than the core features.

Spolsky warns against management pressuring programmers to reduce estimates, as this creates unrealistic schedules that demotivate teams. Instead, if the schedule reveals the project will take longer than desired, the only honest choices are to **delay the ship date or cut features**â€”you cannot "shrink" the necessary work. A well-maintained schedule acts as a truthful forecasting tool.

title: The Home Computer Hybrids
summary:
This article traces the early divergence and eventual convergence of home computer and video game console markets in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Initially, these were separate cultures: computer games (like *Zork* and *Wizardry*) were complex, text-heavy, and had cumbersome loading processes, while console games (like Atari's VCS titles) were simple, plug-and-play arcade-style experiences. However, the massive sales of video game consoles attracted computer makers, and vice-versa, leading to the creation of "home computer hybrids."

These third-generation machines, like the Atari 400/800 and Texas Instruments TI-99/4, combined the programmability and expandability of a personal computer with the dedicated graphics/sound chips and convenient cartridge slots of a game console. Driven by corporate strategy and engineer passion, they aimed to capture both markets. The Atari Home Computer System, in particular, succeeded by offering superior graphics and sound, becoming a top seller by 1982 and demonstrating the viability of a hybrid approach.

The article frames this development as a natural evolution from early dedicated game chips to microprocessor-based consoles, showing how the lines between computers and game consoles began to blur as companies sought to leverage the strengths of both platforms.

title: Quack-Cluster: A Serverless Distributed SQL Query Engine with DuckDB and Ray
summary:
**Quack-Cluster** is a serverless, distributed SQL query engine built with Python, Ray, and DuckDB. It enables high-performance analytics on large datasets stored in object storage (like AWS S3) or local files without requiring complex infrastructure or data movement.

**Key Features:**
*   **Distributed Execution:** Uses Ray to parallelize SQL queries across a cluster of worker nodes, each running an embedded DuckDB instance for fast, in-memory processing.
*   **Direct Data Access:** Queries data directly from Parquet, CSV, and other file formats in cloud storage or filesystems, eliminating ETL.
*   **Python-Native:** Seamlessly integrates into existing Python data workflows.
*   **Rich SQL Support:** Executes complex operations including joins, CTEs, window functions, and aggregations using DuckDB's SQL dialect.

**How It Works:** A user submits a SQL query via a FastAPI endpoint. The coordinator parses the query, creates a distributed execution plan, and assigns tasks to Ray workers. Each worker processes a subset of the data with DuckDB, and partial results are aggregated and returned.

**Getting Started:** The project can be run locally using Docker and `make` commands. It includes sample data generation and a Postman collection for API testing. The roadmap includes future integrations with metadata catalogs and a dedicated Python SDK.

title: Self Driving Car Insurance
summary:
**Summary of "Self Driving Car Insurance" from Lemonade**

The article explains how the rise of autonomous vehicles (AVs) will fundamentally reshape car insurance, shifting liability from human drivers to manufacturers and software developers.

**Key Points:**

*   **Shift in Liability:** In traditional insurance, the driver is at fault for accidents. With fully self-driving cars (SAE Level 5), the "driver" is the AI and its sensors. Therefore, liability for crashes will primarily fall on the **car manufacturers, software companies, and parts suppliers** responsible for the vehicle's operation.
*   **New Insurance Models:** Insurance will likely follow two paths:
    1.  **Manufacturer/Commercial Policies:** Carmakers will carry substantial product liability insurance to cover their autonomous systems.
    2.  **Personal "Rider" Policies:** Individual owners may still need insurance, but it will be simpler and cheaper. It would cover non-crash events like theft, vandalism, fire, or damage from falling objects (comprehensive coverage), not at-fault collisions.
*   **The Transition Period:** The article notes we are in a long transition phase with semi-autonomous features (like Tesla Autopilot). Here, determining fault is complex and may involve both the human driver (for inattention) and the technology, making insurance claims more complicated.
*   **Expected Outcome:** Widespread adoption of AVs is predicted to drastically reduce accidents caused by human error (e.g., drunk driving, distraction). This should make roads much safer and, consequently, make **personal auto insurance significantly less expensive and more straightforward** over time, evolving into minimal "passenger insurance."

In essence, self-driving car insurance will transition from a product centered on human driver risk to one focused on product liability for manufacturers and basic physical damage coverage for car owners.

title: Buttered Crumpet, a custom typeface for Wallace and Gromit
summary:
This case study outlines the creation of "Buttered Crumpet," a custom typeface designed for Aardman's Wallace and Gromit franchise. The brief required a versatile font with a distinct, warm character suitable for film, print, and digital media.

The design process drew inspiration from Oswald Cooper's original Cooper Black drawings but evolved into a softer, low-contrast style with a hand-crafted feel. A distinctive feature is the serifs, which are shaped to resemble loaves of bread, subtly referencing Aardman's tactile and playful animation world.

The final outcome is a single-weight typeface described as timeless and charming, containing over 200 characters that support Western European languages. The designer, who is based in Bristol like Aardman, notes the project's personal significance and the positive reception the font has received upon its initial use.

title: Implementing a tiny CPU rasterizer (2024)
summary: This article introduces a tutorial series on implementing a CPU-based 3D rasterizer from scratch. The author explains that while GPUs handle rendering efficiently, building a CPU rasterizer is a valuable exercise for learning graphics fundamentals, improving programming skills, and understanding GPU internals. The series begins with basic setup: creating a window using SDL2, managing a pixel buffer (surface), and clearing it to a solid color. The author also starts designing a custom graphics API, defining core data types like `color4ub` and `vector4f` for color representation. The goal is to build a simple rendering engine step-by-step, acknowledging that the CPU implementation will be slow but educational.

title: Mamdani to kill the NYC AI chatbot caught telling businesses to break the law
summary:
Mayor Zohran Mamdani plans to shut down New York City's AI chatbot, citing it as a cost-saving measure amid a significant budget deficit. The chatbot, launched by the previous Adams administration in 2023 to help businesses navigate city regulations, was found to frequently provide dangerously incorrect and illegal advice. Investigations by The Markup and THE CITY revealed it told users that businesses could take employees' tips, landlords could discriminate against tenants with housing vouchers, and that refusing cash payments was legalâ€”all of which violate city laws.

Despite initial defenses and promises of improvement from the Adams team, the bot remained flawed, leading to the addition of prominent disclaimers warning users not to rely on its responses. Mamdani criticized the project as "functionally unusable" and a wasteful expenditure, with development costs nearing $600,000. His administration views its termination as a symbolic step in addressing fiscal mismanagement while pursuing broader solutions like tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to close the budget gap.

title: Show HN: Amla Sandbox â€“ WASM bash shell sandbox for AI agents
summary:
**Amla Sandbox** is a WebAssembly (WASM)-based secure execution environment designed for AI agents that generate and run code. It addresses the security risks of traditional methods (like `exec()` or `subprocess.run()`) by providing strict isolation and capability enforcement, preventing arbitrary code execution on the host machine.

Key features include:
*   **WASM Isolation**: Code runs in a sandboxed WASM environment with a virtual filesystem, no network access, and no shell escape.
*   **Capability Security**: Agents can only call explicitly provided tools, with constraints (e.g., parameter limits, allowed values) defined by the developer.
*   **Efficiency**: Allows agents to execute multi-step scripts in a single call, reducing costly LLM round-trips compared to individual tool-calling.
*   **Language Support**: Executes JavaScript and shell scripts, integrating tools via a clear object-based API.
*   **No Infrastructure**: Runs as a single binary without requiring Docker or a VM.

The tool is integrated with frameworks like LangGraph and uses a constraint DSL for fine-grained control. While it doesn't offer a full Linux environment or protect against infinite loops, it provides a lightweight, secure solution for most agent use cases where controlled tool access is paramount. The Python wrapper is MIT-licensed, while the core WASM binary is proprietary.

title: Ode to the AA Battery
summary:
This article is a critique of modern devices with non-replaceable, built-in lithium-ion batteries, praising the reliability and longevity of devices powered by standard, user-replaceable cells like AA and AAA batteries.

The author highlights a common frustration: rechargeable devices often fail after periods of storage because their batteries discharge below a safe voltage, damaging the cell. Since these batteries are difficult or impossible for users to replace, the entire device often becomes e-waste.

In contrast, devices using standard batteries offer superior longevity and repairability. The author uses personal experience with Panasonic Eneloop rechargeable AAs, noting their durability over a decade with minimal failures and no leakage issues. Examples include decades-old electronics like a Sony Walkman that still function with fresh batteries.

For non-portable tools, the author prefers USB-C powered devices for their safety and ubiquity. While acknowledging that sleek designs like smartphones require integrated batteries, the argument is that for many portable tools and electronics, the trade-offs in weight and size are worth the benefits of user serviceability, safety, and reduced waste. The core message advocates for designing more devices around universal, replaceable power sources.

title: How AI assistance impacts the formation of coding skills
summary:
This study, a randomized controlled trial with software developers, investigates how AI coding assistance impacts the learning of new programming skills. Participants were tasked with learning a new Python library, with one group using an AI assistant and a control group coding by hand.

The key finding was that using AI assistance led to a statistically significant decrease in skill mastery. On a follow-up quiz, the AI group scored 17% lower (50% vs. 67%) than the hand-coding group. The largest gap was in debugging skills, crucial for identifying errors in AI-generated code. While the AI group finished tasks slightly faster, this productivity gain was not statistically significant.

Critically, the research found that *how* developers used AI influenced learning outcomes. Low-scoring patterns involved heavy reliance on AI for code generation or debugging, leading to cognitive offloading. High-scoring patterns, however, involved using AI to build comprehensionâ€”asking follow-up questions, requesting explanations, or posing conceptual queries while still coding independently.

The authors conclude that while AI can boost productivity on familiar tasks, it may hinder the acquisition of new skills if used uncritically. This trade-off has implications for workplace AI policies and tool design, emphasizing the need for intentional practices that balance efficiency with ongoing skill development, especially for providing oversight of AI-generated code.

title: Emoji Design Convergence Review: 2018-2026
summary:
This article reviews emoji design trends from 2018 to 2026, highlighting a strong move toward **design convergence**, where major vendors (like Samsung, Google, Microsoft, and Meta) revised their emojis to look more similar. A key pattern is that many vendors aligned their designs with **Apple's set**, which has been a dominant reference point since its early introduction. A prime example is the ğŸ”« Pistol emoji, which most platforms changed to a toy water gun following Apple's lead.

However, the trend is not absolute. There have been notable **instances of divergence**: Apple itself had to revise the ğŸ¤­ Face With Hand Over Mouth to match others, and new emoji proposals aim to clarify existing design inconsistencies. Furthermore, some platforms have intentionally broken from consensus, such as **X (formerly Twitter) reverting the pistol to a realistic firearm** and altering the ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡· Iran flag emoji. New vendor sets from **Huawei** and **Toss** have also introduced culturally specific or stylistically divergent designs.

In summary, while the overall direction since 2018 has been toward greater uniformityâ€”often centered on Apple's designsâ€”purposeful divergence for cultural, political, or branding reasons continues to shape the emoji landscape.

title: HTTP Cats
summary:
This article introduces **HTTP Cats**, a service that provides humorous cat images corresponding to HTTP status codes. The core functionality is simple: users can access an image for any standard status code by visiting the URL `https://http.cat/[status_code]` (optionally adding `.jpg`).

The main body of the content is a comprehensive list of HTTP status codes, from informational (1xx) and success (2xx) codes to redirection (3xx), client error (4xx), and server error (5xx) codes. It includes well-known codes like **200 OK**, **404 Not Found**, and **500 Internal Server Error**, as well as more obscure ones like **418 Iâ€™m a teapot** and **451 Unavailable For Legal Reasons**.

In summary, HTTP Cats is a playful, educational tool for developers that visually maps feline photos to the technical responses of web servers, making the HTTP protocol more approachable and memorable.

title: Code is cheap. Show me the talk
summary:
This article argues that the advent of LLM coding tools has fundamentally ended traditional software development. Historically, writing quality code was a high-effort, high-skill endeavor constrained by human cognitive and physical limits. The adage "talk is cheap, show me the code" reflected the significant value of the final, handcrafted artifact.

Now, LLMs can instantly generate vast amounts of well-structured, functional code, making the act of coding itself "cheap." This destroys traditional rule-of-thumb signals for evaluating software quality, as stunning documentation and neat code no longer indicate developer expertise or effort. While this allows experienced developers to prototype and build complex systems orders of magnitude faster, it also floods the ecosystem with AI-generated "slop."

The author contends that code's value is no longer in its creation but in the **human accountability and intent** behind it. A human-written pull request carries intrinsic value from the effort expended, whereas an LLM-generated one feels like a burden, creating a "Library of Babel" scenario of infinite, low-effort variations. This shift particularly challenges the Free and Open Source Software (FOSS) ecosystem, which was built on the premise of code as a valuable, collaboratively built commons. The core conclusion is that the era of software development defined by the high cost of writing code is over.

title: Pangolin (YC S25) is hiring software engineers (open-source, Go, networking)
summary:
Pangolin (YC S25) is hiring software engineers to build its secure remote access platform, which replaces traditional VPNs. The company provides identity-aware access to internal applications and services, emphasizing open-source development and self-hosted deployment for customer control.

The platform is policy-driven, integrates with standard identity providers, and offers observability and automation APIs. Ideal candidates are passionate about open-source software, networking, and security.

Two open roles are specified: Software Engineer - Full Stack and Software Engineer - Go + Network.

title: Vcad: Free BRep CAD in the Browser
summary:
**Summary of "Vcad: Free BRep CAD in the Browser"**

Vcad is a free, open-source, browser-based CAD application built on the Boundary Representation (BRep) solid modeling kernel. Its primary goal is to make professional-grade parametric 3D modeling accessible directly within a web browser, eliminating the need for software installation or powerful local hardware.

The core of Vcad is its use of the Open CASCADE Technology (OCCT) kernel, which is compiled to WebAssembly to run efficiently in the browser. This allows users to perform complex solid modeling operations like extrusions, fillets, and Boolean operations entirely online.

Key features highlighted include its parametric workflow, where models are defined by a history tree of editable features, enabling easy design iteration. The interface is designed to be intuitive for users familiar with desktop CAD software. Furthermore, Vcad supports importing and exporting standard CAD file formats like STEP and BREP, facilitating integration into existing design workflows.

As a free and open-source project, Vcad represents a significant step toward democratizing advanced CAD tools, making them available for education, prototyping, and professional use directly through a web link.

title: Wisconsin communities signed secrecy deals for billion-dollar data centers
summary:
This article details how secrecy has surrounded the development of several massive data center projects in Wisconsin, raising transparency concerns. A Wisconsin Watch investigation found that in at least four communitiesâ€”Beaver Dam, Menomonie, Kenosha, and Janesvilleâ€”local officials used nondisclosure agreements (NDAs) with developers to keep billion-dollar proposals hidden from the public for over a year. Even in towns without formal NDAs, like DeForest and Port Washington, officials worked on plans for months before public announcements, leading to resident backlash.

The secrecy is defended by economic developers as necessary to protect corporate strategy, but critics argue these projectsâ€”which dramatically impact land use, energy, taxes, and the environmentâ€”require early public input. The lack of disclosure has fueled opposition, including a proposed recall in Port Washington and a new state bill from Rep. Clint Moses to ban data center NDAs entirely. The article notes similar secrecy issues and legislative pushes against NDAs are occurring nationwide, as communities grapple with balancing economic development with public transparency and the risk of creating costly "stranded" utility assets.

title: Microsoft 365 now tracks you in real time?
summary:
**Summary:**

Microsoft is introducing a real-time location tracking feature for Microsoft 365, scheduled for release in March 2026. This update will allow managers to see an employee's precise location during work hours via the Teams application on Windows, Mac, and mobile devices.

The system works by detecting and displaying the name of the Wi-Fi network an employee is connected to, such as a home or public network (e.g., "Starbucks_Guest_WiFi"). This effectively ends the ability to appear generically "remote" and makes it difficult to disguise one's actual whereabouts.

Microsoft states the feature includes privacy safeguards: it is optional for organizations to enable, tracking is confined to working hours, and location history is automatically deleted. However, the article expresses skepticism, arguing that if an employer mandates its use, employees have little practical choice.

The author characterizes the update as a significant invasion of privacy for hybrid and remote workers, comparing it to a "digital ankle monitor" and viewing it as an excessive tool for managerial oversight rather than a legitimate coordination tool.

title: Netflix Animation Studios Joins the Blender Development Fund as Corporate Patron
summary:
Netflix Animation Studios has joined the Blender Development Fund as a Corporate Patron, a move announced on January 27, 2026. This partnership signifies Netflix's strategic investment in the open-source 3D software Blender, with its support directed toward general core development to enhance tools for media and entertainment creators.

Blender Foundation CEO Francesco Siddi highlighted the membership as a major recognition of Blender's growing role in high-end animation studio pipelines and an investment in a diverse, open-source creative ecosystem. Darin Grant, SVP of Global Technology at Netflix Animation Studios, stated that this reflects their commitment to supporting open-source software and that Netflix is proud to be the first major animation studio to back Blender's development and adoption by professionals.

The announcement underscores Blender's established position as the world's most popular free and open-source 3D creation suite, maintained by the Blender Foundation for a global community of artists.

title: GOG: Linux "the next major frontier" for gaming as it works on a native client
summary:
GOG, the digital game store known for classic and retro-style titles, is developing a native Linux version of its GOG Galaxy desktop client. The company has declared Linux "the next major frontier" for gaming and is actively hiring a senior engineer to shape the client's architecture for the platform from the ground up.

This move follows GOG's recent change in ownership and its strategy to carve out a niche in a market dominated by Steam. While GOG Galaxy is optional for playing purchased games, a native Linux version would provide a more integrated experience for managing libraries and community features without relying on compatibility layers like Proton.

The development signals GOG's commitment to appealing to the Linux gaming community, which has grown significantly due to advancements in compatibility technology. A native client aims to give Linux users a smoother way to access and enjoy classic games from GOG's catalog.

title: Grid: Free, local-first, browser-based 3D printing/CNC/laser slicer
summary:
**Grid.Space** is a free, browser-based platform for 3D printing, CNC machining, and laser cutting, designed specifically for education. It eliminates common barriers by requiring no software installation, licenses, or user accountsâ€”students simply open a web browser to start.

The platform prioritizes privacy and accessibility: all work is processed locally on the studentâ€™s device, ensuring data security and compliance with regulations like COPPA/FERPA. It works on any modern computer or Chromebook, functions offline after loading, and is free forever with no subscriptions.

Grid.Space teaches real-world digital fabrication skills, including model slicing, CAM toolpath generation, and 2D design preparation for laser cutting. It is positioned as an ideal, cost-free solution for K-12 schools, makerspaces, universities, libraries, and homeschool environments, supporting STEM, art, and design curricula.

Compared to commercial software, its key advantages are zero cost, no installation, automatic updates, full platform support, local data processing, and open-source accessibility under an MIT license. Getting started involves visiting the website, with extensive resources available for educators and students.

summary:

The content is a standard error message from the social media platform X (formerly Twitter), stating that JavaScript is disabled in the user's browser. title: AGENTS.md outperforms skills in our agent evals
summary:
This article details an experiment comparing two methods for providing AI coding agents with up-to-date Next.js 16 documentation: using "skills" (on-demand toolkits) versus embedding a compressed index in an `AGENTS.md` file.

The key finding was that the passive `AGENTS.md` approach dramatically outperformed skills. In evaluations, a compressed 8KB docs index in `AGENTS.md` achieved a 100% pass rate, while skills maxed out at 79% only when paired with explicit instructions. Without those instructions, skills performed no better than having no documentation at all, as agents often failed to invoke them.

The authors theorize `AGENTS.md` is more effective because it eliminates decision points (the agent doesn't need to choose to look up information), ensures consistent availability in the system prompt, and avoids sequencing issues. To prevent context bloat, the documentation is compressed into a minimal index that points to full docs stored locally.

The article concludes that for general framework knowledge, passive context in `AGENTS.md` is currently the most reliable method to shift agents from outdated training data to "retrieval-led reasoning." A command (`npx @next/codemod@canary agents-md`) is available to automatically set this up for Next.js projects.
